block.p: Trial of Milosevic Opens; Power Cited as His Motive The chief prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal accused the ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic of committing genocide and other crimes against humanity out of a pure lust for power.
Russian Secrecy Order Voided Russia's Supreme Court struck down a 1996 military secrecy order and handed civil-liberties advocates a potentially crucial victory.

Trial of Milosevic Opens; Power Cited as His Motive The chief prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal accused the ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic of committing genocide and other crimes against humanity out of a pure lust for power.
Russian Secrecy Order Voided Russia's Supreme Court struck down a 1996 military secrecy order and handed civil-liberties advocates a potentially crucial victory.
Passenger Jet Crashes in Iran An Iranian airliner crashed in the mountains of western Iran. All 118 aboard were believed dead.

U.S. Sharpens Focus on Iraq; Weighs Ouster of Hussein Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the Bush administration was weighing options to topple Saddam Hussein, signaling a growing consensus within the administration over the next phase in the war on terror.

Survivors Recall U.S. Raid Survivors of an American air raid in Afghanistan on Oct. 21 said the strike killed only civilians -- 21 people from two families, including 17 children and 3 women -- who were trying to flee their village.

Britain Releases Algerian Lotfi Raissi, an Algerian pilot held in Britain on charges of having direct links to the Sept. 11 hijackers, was freed on $14,200 bail after the lawyer representing the United States said the government no longer intended to press terrorism charges.

Kidnapping Suspect in Custody Pakistani officials arrested Ahmed Omar Sheikh, an Islamic militant who is the main suspect in the kidnapping of the journalist Daniel Pearl, and said he had told them that the American was alive.

Aid to bin Laden Cited A senior official of Afghanistan's interim government, Yunus Qanooni, said elements in Pakistan's intelligence service had helped Osama bin Laden and Mullah Mohammad Omar evade capture.

Al Qaeda Figures in Warning Suspected members of Osama bin Laden's network are believed to be among the 17 men identified in the latest terror alert issued by the F.B.I. that warns of an attack in the United States or Yemen.

Defending Detentions The Justice Department created a team of lawyers headed by Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson to defend against any court challenges to the policy of detaining terror suspects indefinitely on a base in Cuba.
Army Denies Mistreatment The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff rejected accusations that American forces beat or kicked captives following a raid last month.
Advance in Anthrax Inquiry A researcher studying the anthrax-mailings case for the F.B.I. said he had distinguished between stocks of the strain kept in different labs.

G.O.P. Leaders Seek Alternative Campaign Bill House Republican leaders sought to shape campaign finance legislation that would fracture a coalition of Democrats and Republicans who support the landmark Shays-Meehan bill banning large unlimited contributions to the political parties. Critical votes are expected today.
House Republicans assailed the Shays-Meehan measure as an infringement on speech.

Backing for Pentagon Budget Democrats joined Republicans on the House Budget Committee in expressing strong support for increasing spending for the military, though both sides raised questions about the long-term costs of some weapons systems in the Bush budget.

Mayor Looks to Save Money By Paring Uniformed Ranks Mayor Bloomberg is expected to announce today that he will cut the size of the 39,110-officer police force by trimming the jobs of 1,600 through attrition. The Fire Department, with 11,500 uniformed members, would lose about 275 firefighter slots.

New Senator for East Side Liz Krueger, a Democrat, beat Assemblyman John Ravitz, a Republican, in a special election for the vacant State Senate seat that was held for more than 30 years by Roy M. Goodman, a Republican.

Olympic Skating Inquiry The International Skating Union said it would investigate whether its rules and procedures were followed in the controversial awarding of the gold medal in pairs figure skating to a Russian couple on Monday.
Westminster Dog Show A miniature poodle, Surrey Spice Girl, was named best in show.
Frank Crosetti The former Yankee infielder and coach who wore the pinstripes for 37 consecutive seasons was 91.
Oscar Nominations ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' led all comers, with 13, including for best picture.

Enron Ex-Chairman's Appeal Kenneth L. Lay asked the Senate Commerce Committee not to rush to judgment on his role in Enron's collapse, but declined to discuss it by asserting his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
Bristol-ImClone Tensions ImClone Systems rejected demands by Bristol-Myers Squibb to restructure their $2 billion agreement to develop and market a cancer drug.
No U.S. Inquiry of Explorer The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration denied a request by Bridgestone/Firestone to investigate Ford Explorer safety defects.
